Drawing on the experiences of REOPA and other innovative public works programmes aiming at permanently lifting extreme poor people out of poverty, SWAPNO will be a cash transfer project for women representing ultra poor and vulnerable households.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Department of Public Health Kakrail, Dhaka

description.narrative: second-order administrative division
third-order administrative division
policy, planning and administration

1. Number of rural extreme poor women employed [Project operational in 2015] 2. Percentage of beneficiary children 0 - 5 years old with complete immunizations [Project operational in 2015] 3. Percentage of beneficiary women with improved health status (self-reported) as against baseline status [Project operational in 2015] 4. Number of people with access to improved economic infrastructure (roads, markets, etc.) as a result of public works completed through the project [Project operational in 2015] 5. Percentage of local government institutions sensitive to inclusiveness (including gender aspects) and able to make pro-poor plans [Project operational in 2015]

comment.narrative: A total of 4464 extreme rural poor women continued their employment in 2016 under SWAPNO. These women were engaged in public asset maintenance, and these jobs helped provide them with a steady and reliable income. This public asset maintenance includes maintaining rural earthen roads to local facilities, maintaining public fields, raising grounds for flood protection, and establishing embankments. As of 2016, all 4464 SWAPNO women benefited from Rotating Savings and Credit Associations (ROSCA), allowing them to generate enough one-time income to invest in other Income Generating Activities (IGAs) to supplement their income and allow them to provide an income for themselves once they exit the SWAPNO project. The 4464 SWAPNO women benefitted from training around maintaining and expanding their chosen Income Generating Activities, which will allow them to provide an income for themselves and dependents for the long-term. The project carried out an economic mapping exercise to guide the small business opportunities for the women. This mapping of market opportunities informed the training plans.

comment.narrative: The National Urban Poverty Reduction Programme (NUPRP) was initiated in early 2016 with an inception phase. Major accomplishments of 2016 included i) five output specific strategy documents developed including preparation of operational guidelines completed, ii) results framework developed including setting up of RELU (Research, Evaluation and Learning Unit), iii) recruitment of 5 output coordinators and core staff members of operations team recruited and trained; iv) Project document formulated and submitted to ERD and DPP formulation process initiated; and v) city wide poverty mapping methodology developed and tested in 2 cities.

description.narrative: 1.1 Number of submissions made by NHRC- B to international human rights instruments /mechanisms (Human rights council, UPR, treaty bodies and special procedures. 1.2 Number of dialogues/ consultations held by NHRC with government authorities and CSOs for preparation of reports to international Human Rights mechanisms. 2.1 Number of coalitions formed through the challenge fund to advance Human Rights initiatives/actions of CSOs/CBOs at grassroots level. 2.2 Number of rights forums jointly undertaken by NHRC thematic committees and CSOs to discuss contemporary human right issues. 3.1 Number of cases reported against law enforcement agencies and police to NHRC. 3.2 Number of times the police take part in human rights dialogues with the NHRC and CSOs. 4.1 % of school students (including teachers) that have a better understanding on women and girl’s rights after campaigns. 4.2 Number of complaints of women’s rights violations submitted to the NHRC by the Committee on Violence Against Women and Children (NNPC) and CSOs/CBOs. 5.1 Number of community radio stations broadcasting minority language programming and rights education programmes. 5.2 % of youth leaders trained have become active in transforming their leadership role to promote the rights of ethnic minorities.

comment.narrative: - NHRC’s capacity enhanced in making submissions to international human rights instruments/mechanisms (Human rights council, UPR, treaty bodies and special procedures) - Rights forums jointly with NHRC thematic committees are able to undertake discussions on contemporary human right issues and the recommendations made by rights forums resulting in implementation or policy advice or procedural changes - Coalitions formed through the challenge fund are better able to advance human rights initiatives/actions at grassroots level

1.1 03 (ICCPR- International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights; CMW- Committee of Migrant Workers; UPR- Universal Periodic Review have been submitted) 1.2 09 consultations were conducted (CMW -1, UPR - 8) 2.1 15 CSO Coalitions formed at local and national level. 2.2 11 rights forums formed and actively function under the thematic committees of NHRC, B in addressing contemporary human rights issues. 3.1 50% 3.2 02 Two dialogues held with Police engaging NHRC and HRP 4.1 10% 4.2 50% 5.1 02 Community Radio Sarabela and Community Radio NAF stations are broadcasting ethnic minority language programming and rights education programmes 5.2 67% youth leaders active in addressing human rights concerns/issues of ethnic minority groups

title.narrative: Promoting Low Carbon Urban Development in Bangladesh

description.narrative: Promoting Low Carbon Urban Development in Bangladesh

The objective of the GEF PPG is to develop the project concept into a full project: Promoting Low Carbon Urban Development in Bangladesh. As described in the project identification format (PIF- project concept), this project’s objective is to reduce GHG emission by enabling investments in renewable energy, energy-efficiency and conservation and waste-to-energy applications to support urban development in Bangladesh.
